why do you use 'kilo' prefix if you talk about numbers that large? If you choose to use a prefix, 'zetta' could come in handy. People can't comprehend billion trillion more than 10^21.

But the moon's recession is slowing down, so that number's probably off by several orders of magnitude. (Such rash calculations also give the moon as a mere 1.6 gigayears old).

Interestingly enough, and unrelated to your question, the Moon is more affected by the Sun than the Earth, so it could really be classified as a co-planet of ours. 

“…to an observer in space the Moon 
must appear as a normal planet, traveling
in an elliptical orbit with the Sun in one of
the foci.” (Moore 2001)

I'm not Derek, but I'll try to answer q1. The moon is moving away at about 4cm/year and, although it's not constant, let's use that. I assume by 'out of our vision' you mean with our eyes and not telescopes which could see it, well, at least to Pluto's orbit.

The eye can see about 0.7 arc-minutes (0.01166.. degrees), meaning something 3474.2km wide would need to be about 17,061,979km away, or about .1 AU. At it's current rate, that would take about 4 million years.

As Derek said, you utilize proteins in your muscle cells. The cells themselves take the protein in and convert it into beta tubulin dimers to make microtubules, actin and myosin fibers. The fibers run the length of the cell and make them longer. Actin and myosin work together to contract your muscles and the more there is, the harder the muscle cells contracts. That's why body builders drink and eat protein often.

You get bigger muscles by damaging your muscle fibers while working out. Then you eat carbohydrates, protein, and omega3 fatty acids for your lipid intakes to replenish your muscle fibers. These nutrients will repair your micro-teared fibers adding length into them. Think about tearing microfilaments but then you quickly replenish it with more protein blocks to add length. So if you replenish more than you can metabolize, you are adding mass.

Okay, but that is a point about language rather than one about physics. In the SI system, each unit has a well defined meaning. Based on that system, kilowatts and kilojoules are not the same thing. One measures power, the other energy. If some quantity has units of mass, of course we can convert to whatever other unit of mass we want. We cannot, however, somehow convert it to a unit of force.

What you're talking about is kilowatt hours. One kilowatt hour is the energy used in running one thousand watts, for an hour, which is also equivalent to 3,600,000 joules. Most of the time people don't specify that they're talking about kilowatt hours, and they just say kilowatts, which technically is a rate of energy, not an amount. However, he did say "the total energy 'radiated' by the sun, averages..." which would be a rate, and not an amount, therefor he was right in saying kilowatts.

Kilowatts and kilojoules are not at all the same! A kilowatt is a kilojoule per second. We can convert between different 'flavors' of the same unit (like meters to inches, or meters to centimeters), but we cannot just convert to some arbitrary unit. That would be like me telling you, "I weigh 17 Volts." You would be very confused because the Volt is not a unit of mass or force. The discrepancy here comes from whether we are talking about the power, OR the 'power' during some time (the energy).

It depends on what we're talking about. We could talk about (1) The power output by the sun (per second), in which case we would use kilowatts OR (2) The power output by the sun IN A CERTAIN TIME (a day, a year, etc), in which case we would measure it in kilojoules. In the 2nd case, we are actually talking about how much total ENERGY the sun puts out during some time period. IN both cases we say 'power' in English, but one means the energy per second, the other means the total energy.
